headline.main: Strong Bones, With and Without Drugs

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column describes differences between osteopenia and osteoporosis and ways both can be controlled and treated; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A 77-year-old woman from Plainview, N.Y., wrote that after a recent bone density test, she was told she had osteopenia. Although she is very active, takes 1,500 milligrams of calcium and 400 international units of vitamin D every day and uses a vaginal estrogen cream, her internist and gynecologist recommend that she take medication to rebuild lost bone and prevent further loss.

headline.main: In Middle Schools, After 'Just Say No'

docs.abstract: Dr Gilbert Botvin, founder of LifeSkills Training, nationally recognized school-based tobacco, alcohol and drug use prevention program, says program, which incorporates scientific research, succeeds in teaching teenagers that smoking and drinking are bad for them; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE problems associated with teenage substance abuse extend beyond the specific health risks associated with a particular substance, like tobacco or alcohol. A new survey recently released from the Kaiser Family Foundation found that more than a quarter of adolescents who drank or used drugs said that substance use influenced their decision to engage in sexual activity.

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: An Effort To Make Smokers Think Twice

docs.abstract: Health Ministry of Brazil orders tobacco companies to display on cigarette packs photos showing effects of smoking; Brazil has been tightening regulations on tobacco industry since 1995, banning cigarette advertisements at sporting and cultural events and forbidding smoking in enclosed areas (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Ministry has ordered tobacco companies to display on cigarette packs photographs showing the effects of smoking. Of the five pictures, one shows premature babies breathing through tubes and another shows a depressed couple in bed after an unsuccessful attempt at sex. Brazil has tightened regulations on the tobacco industry since 1995, banning cigarette advertisements at sporting and cultural events and on television until 11 p.m., and forbidding smoking in enclosed areas. Mery Galanternick (NYT)
